6LKdxG3Y2QpIDrVrAtQZrg.text: I didn't eat here but my idea of "comfort" food is different.   I couldn't sit where I wanted "because we get really busy"  and was stuck by a utility door because I made the mistake of coming here alone and didn't want to sit at the bar.  They kept getting into the door, which wasn't pleasant.  I looked at the menu and not a burger in sight and some crazy prices. I kid you not.  $12 for mac-n-cheese, $35 for steak, and $20 for chicken and waffles.  The steak sounded awesome, though!  If I could have sat at a nice table, maybe the prices wouldn't be an issue but to charge them and not even being "comfortable" and made to feel like coming there as a single person gets me the crappy table.....well, I got up and left.  I can get a better table, gorganzola steak, and not made to feel that being a single diner is an imposition at another restaurant.

svSVHXAKuAdO2oTFRswGDg.text: You are going to want to start with drinks (always).  The 13 and 14 are a whiskey lovers instant favorite.  The 13 is going to come off like a figgy Old Fashioned, and the 14 is a bit more unique, sweeter with rye as the primary spirit, but well-balanced nonetheless.  You cannot go wrong with either.  There is also a dangerous blue berry, vodka or gin heavy beverage that comes out cloudy white that you can drink all night.  For red wine go with a malbec, they have outstanding choices.  They also have some rare aged whiskies that are going to change based on availability, but ask if you are hurting for brown liquor on its own.  For white wine, you are on your own.  I don't go there.  On to food.  Do not deny yourself the fried cheese curds.  They come out crispy, melty, salty and sauceless, and so right.  They are really the essence of cheesiness.  They have a delicate flavor though, so you do not really need some overwhelming aioli mucking things up.  Next, try the baguette with roasted garlic and olive oil.  Simple logic here: fantastic ingredients perfectly executed.  They bring you a whole roasted garlic, sitting in a little pool of olive oil, and it spreads like butter on soft slightly toasted baguette.  Carbs, good oil, and bliss.  Your breath is going to be garlicky.  If you are on a date and your date is not into that, get a new date.  You are going to be distracted by the many main dish  offerings.  Get the gnocchi.  Growing up with an Italian grandmother, you learn to appreciate a good gnocchi when you taste one.  Camille would approve of Tuck Shop's super tender gnocchi clouds, airy on the inside, with slight crisp on the outside from the pan frying treatment.  They come in a cheesy sauce, which is strong on the parmigiano, and thick and creamy.  I cannot remember the last time I had gnocchi this good.  Highly recommended.  My mom loves gnocchi, so I know where I'm taking her for mother's day.  Finally, get the Lobstah Mac and Cheese.  Warning long winded preface incoming.  I am not a mac and cheese guy.  So often it is just sludgy cheese sauce and overcooked slimy noodles.  Adding lobster on your average mac and cheese (or mashed potatos while we are on the subject) is like putting a big block V-8 into a wrecked Ford Pinto; you are taking something great, and putting it into an unmitigated mess.  Lobster mac and cheese in general is more idea than food.  It always sounds better than it is.  It occupies the imagination as dare-not decadent; the kind of showy food that a gold miner would order for his hookers after hitting the mother lode; the kind of thing Camille, who survived the Great Depression, would be ashamed of me for ordering, wasting good money ; the combination of the comdortable and familiar and unexperienced luxary: the embodiment of the American Dream, and just as elusive: classic Americana that's grown-up, sexed-up, and classed-up with little something extra, a little something rare, a little something different.  I went to those lengths to talk about everything Tuck Shop's Lobstah Mac and Cheese is not.  It is fucking great.  I added with lobster (obviously) and got the bacon on the side (for maximum crispness).  The pasta was al dente, the cheese sauce was rich and creamy, without being overly decadent, the baked topping is a pleasant textural contrast with a subtle crunch.  The lobster was cooked right, and did not get lost in what is usually an overwhelming setting.  The name of the game here is balance.  It is everything the Tuck Shop represents.  In closing, Tuck Shop is a place every 20 or 30 something who grew up in Arizona needs to experience.  Aside from the killer food, drinks, and service, Tuck Shop more importantly reflects the latest example of the cultural renaissance Phoenix is experiencing.  The children of Arizona, like Grace Unger, are staying or returning home with the dream of transforming our sleepy desert town into a racuous food, drink, and entertainment capital with its own saguaro laced flavor.  It is a thriving business that sprouted out of the once ailing Coronado neighborhood, which is helmed by a young female entrepreneur who takes your dining experience personally.  Grace wants you to be happy.  She wants to get to know everyone who walks in her door.  She, like Tuck Shop, is instantly familiar, fun, and Classed-Up Classic.  I hope you love it here as much as I do.  See you at the bar!

OCOyOGKBTAo3tkkW71C9FQ.text: We thoroughly enjoyed our experience here.  We sampled many small plates and then split a meal.  Wouldn't hesitate to go back.

L1gt8VAmUo7H0XdmlBKa3A.text: Cheese curds and wine in a great neighborhood spot. 'Nuff said. The rest of the food is good too!  A great spot for the little better than casual date night or a dinner with friends...

j2XHeZcrfJXsbF78_fpglA.text: Update: The Tuck Shop has changed owners, and, at the moment, the ridiculous pre-paid reservation requirement has gone away. I'm glad the new owners have corrected this and I hope to come back in soon after the menu / space has been updated.

StSfjY2VuV-YUZlqqBq5Tg.text: Thoroughly outstanding food, service and originality.  Located in a quiet neighborhood near downtown this place has it all.  Retro vibe with couches like we had in our home in the 60's, small intimate bar seating, a nice view of the kitchen and a small number of tables.  Went with my daughter and her husband and we had appetizers and small plates.  For apps we had the cheese curds and Sonoran style "pigs in a blanket" made with a local craft sausage....curds were smooth, creamy and had a mysterious spice that moved them over the top and the dogs were unique, spicy and filled with flavor.  For small plates we had the spicy shrimp that was perfectly prepared and as good as what you get in New Orleans, next we had the Lobster Mac and Cheese, utterly sumptuous.  The huge hit was the Pork Belly with a little frisee salad that was perfectly prepared, sweet, savory and just plain delicious.  It may be out of the way but it's worth the trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Tuck Shop - Phoenix, AZ, United States

9efEGfCeiEM52yPmSjG5_g.text: Fine neighborhood jewel.  Go!  Excellent food, service and ambience.  Also Astor house next door meets same high quality standards.  Remarkable chefs!

NONTvsWi7EeNSnbPWkwCmA.text: Food:  - 5 stars!!! - Cheese curds, gazpacho, lamb meatballs, pork tenderloin, mac and cheese, stuffed dates - 4 stars - chicken and waffles, fillet w/ gnocchi  Drinks:  - 5 stars!!! - Rye whisky old fashioned - 3 stars - French 75  Favorites: Lamb meatballs, tenderloin, cheese curds, dates, gazpacho  Service: Accommodating, knowledgeable staff and service.  Ambiance: Mid century modern decor with a romantic and cozy feel. Love it!  Overall, one of the best restaurants in Phoenix bar far. Very impressed. Can't wait to go back.

huoVC1IRpM3YaIVMK8cZaQ.text: A quaint neighborhood restaurant. A full bar, small tables nicely decorated. The service was great. I had the portabella melt.....WONDERFUL! The gingerale is very different and refreshing. I especially enjoyed the strips of fresh cantaloupe with sprinkled herbs. I noticed the gals next to my table were truly enjoying the cheese curds. I will try next time around. A pleasant experience for my first time. We got there right a five, the place fills up fast. There is additional parking across the street.

Cm_Zblzj-hXcx8yBUuMyOw.text: I'm not from the Phoenix area so when I searched for best restaurants for dinner, Tuck Shop was one of many that came up. The reviews and menu seemed solid so I booked a reservation with the restaurant directly through Yelp.  I mentioned in the reservation comments that it was my girlfriends birthday and when we arrived they did not disappoint.   Upon arrival the hostess wished her happy birthday which put a big smile on her face.  They gave us a nice seat in the back corner which felt private and the waitress greeted us with 2 glasses of complimentary prosecco garnished with a slice of strawberry.  The food was delicious and the overall experience and service helped make her birthday dinner memorable.   The meal and drinks: We shared a bunch of small plates: - Shrimp Piri Piri - amazing, nice sized shrimp with the right amount of spice. It was difficult not licking the plate - Pork Belly - delicious- nuff said - Tuna tartare - nice firm tuna with a perfect arugula garnish - also a plate licking struggle - Stuffed dates - with chorizo and gruyere that literally melted in our mouths - we had the No. 51 and No. 57 for cocktails which were both mezcal based and paired nicely with all the dishes  To round off the experience they produced a delicious apple fritter thingy with a candle for dessert that was light and not too sweet.

Bq-SbOtoiqQdJ-aP4Qza3w.text: Food was really good.  Cheddar waffle was great, bourbon maple syrup was awesome! Just a little pricey. Two people came up to $46 including tax and tip. For breakfast it's a bit too much, but I'd return to this place. Area of restaurant is a little ghetto.

DWFY8-1txUIYAbtLaxLl7Q.text: How do I not have a review for the tuck shop is beyond me. Every single time I am here 2 things stand out -  a) The service, really is what Barney would call .. legend... wait for it.. -ary ! b) The food is delicious !   Given that it is located in the Coronado historic district there isn't a patio (zoning regs), and the restaurant itself is hidden unless you knew it was there. There is ample parking available in the empty lot across the street which is always a plus.  It does get busy so I would recommend making reservations ahead of time. They are very accommodating if you are trying to organize something or the other and will try to make it work.   They do go out of their way to make you feel welcome and heck even if you weren't a regular they still make you feel like one. The staff is polite and courteous to a fault, and never have i ever felt rushed at the place. They even ask you in what order you would like your food, so its not like there is a lot on your plate all of a sudden.   There is a plethora of vegetarian options and they will try to make adjustments if they are feasible. I always thought that was very nice of them to do so. The food is consistently good and while the management may have changed over time the food tastes consistently good.   All things said, it is on the pricier side, and so there is that but honestly the food, the atmosphere and the service makes it worth it.

5VCIj4bkeaZO6vsjX-3Apw.text: WOW!  Atmosphere: Delightful comfortable charm perfect for adult dinner celebratory or intimate dinning. Service: Totally on-point timing, accommodating, humor and wit! PERFECT! Cocktails: AWESOME! IMAGINATIVE and delicious  - Rum and beet juice - who woulda thought!  WOW.  Food: From the first bite to the last its evident these meals must be made with LOVE. We grazed on apps plus a bunch of small plates - delightfully pleased/surprises/very satisfying! Delicious falls short describing every dish we had, including desert!  We wanted to have easy dinner conversation -  adult siblings & spouses plus good food - expectations exceeded! The after-glow is still with us! We will go back!

sPPl3ZsLfsD5oV4PlBGmWw.text: Everything about this place is totally awesome. The server was absolute doll to explain everything to us. Love the atmosphere of the place!  We ordered a bunch of small plates to try and share. Got the mac and cheese, gnocchi, & risotto.  They were all delicious and so good. The vanilla bean creme brulee was outstanding.
